fgeo.abundance 0.0.0.9002
  • Get started

  • fgeo

Count number of individuals in total or by groups.

Source: R/abundance.R

Count number of individuals in total (abundance_tally()) or by groups (abundance()). These functions wrap functions in the dplyr package to provide shortcuts similar to those in the original CTFSRPackage (see Warning).

abundance(x, group_by = c("quadrat", "sp"), only_alive = TRUE)

abundance_tally(x, only_alive = TRUE)

Arguments

x

Census data.
group_by

Character string giving the names of variables to group by.
only_alive

If TRUE, counts only alive individuals (`status == "A"`). If FALSE counts individuals of all available statuses.

Value

  • abundance_tally(): An integer giving the number of rows in x, which for census data equals the number of unique individuals.

  • abundance(): a data frame giving the number of individuals in each group defined by group_by.

Warning

You should prefer using dplyr dirctly (see Examples) -- it is more explicit and general, which will make your code more readable by people outside ForestGEO.

See also

dplyr::tally(), dplyr::count().

Other grouped summaries: basal_area

Examples

stem <- bciex::bci12s7mini

# Returns a data frame by groups
n <- abundance(stem)
head(n)
#>   quadrat     sp n
#> 1    0000 soroaf 1
#> 2    0002 hybapr 1
#> 3    0006 hybapr 2
#> 4    0009 faraoc 1
#> 5    0009 hybapr 1
#> 6    0020 tet2pa 1

# Instead of a data frame, return an integer representing a tally
abundance_tally(stem)
#> [1] 665

# Count not only alive
n <- abundance(stem, group_by = c("status", "sp"), only_alive = FALSE)
ordered_by_species <- order(n$sp)
head(n[ordered_by_species, ])
#>     status     sp  n
#> 1        A acaldi  5
#> 112      D acaldi 11
#> 222      G acaldi 11
#> 113      D aegipa  1
#> 114      D alchco  1
#> 223      G alchco 10



# ALTERNATIVE: Prefer dplyr; it is more general and explicit
library(dplyr)

alive <- dplyr::filter(stem, status == "A")
grouped <- count(alive, quadrat, sp)

census <- tibble(
  stemID = 1:6,
  quadrat = paste0("000", rep(1:2, each = 3)),
  sp = c(paste0("sp", c(1, 1, 2)), paste0("sp", c(3, 3, 3))),
  dbh = abs(sample(rnorm(100), 6) * 10)
)
census
#> # A tibble: 6 x 4
#>   stemID quadrat sp        dbh
#>    <int> <chr>   <chr>   <dbl>
#> 1      1 0001    sp1    1.12  
#> 2      2 0001    sp1    0.381 
#> 3      3 0001    sp2    3.63  
#> 4      4 0002    sp3    0.0557
#> 5      5 0002    sp3   16.3   
#> 6      6 0002    sp3   13.0   

# Abundance (rows count) by quadrat
count(census, quadrat)
#> # A tibble: 2 x 2
#>   quadrat     n
#>   <chr>   <int>
#> 1 0001        3
#> 2 0002        3
# same
census %>% count(quadrat)
#> # A tibble: 2 x 2
#>   quadrat     n
#>   <chr>   <int>
#> 1 0001        3
#> 2 0002        3

# Abundance (rows count) by species
count(census, sp)
#> # A tibble: 3 x 2
#>   sp        n
#>   <chr> <int>
#> 1 sp1       2
#> 2 sp2       1
#> 3 sp3       3

# Abundance (rows count) by quadrat by species
count(census, quadrat, sp)
#> # A tibble: 3 x 3
#>   quadrat sp        n
#>   <chr>   <chr> <int>
#> 1 0001    sp1       2
#> 2 0001    sp2       1
#> 3 0002    sp3       3
# same
census %>% count(quadrat, sp)
#> # A tibble: 3 x 3
#>   quadrat sp        n
#>   <chr>   <chr> <int>
#> 1 0001    sp1       2
#> 2 0001    sp2       1
#> 3 0002    sp3       3


# Richness by quadrat:
# Count is designed so that you can call it repeatedly, each time rolling up a
# level of detail.
# Now, each row by quadrat is a unique species, so counting rows gives
richness
#> Error in eval(expr, envir, enclos): object 'richness' not found
census %>%
  count(quadrat, sp) %>%
  count(quadrat)
#> # A tibble: 2 x 2
#>   quadrat    nn
#>   <chr>   <int>
#> 1 0001        2
#> 2 0002        1

# Singleton:
# add_count() is useful for groupwise filtering e.g.: show only species that
# have a single member
census %>%
  add_count(quadrat, sp) %>%
  filter(n == 1)
#> # A tibble: 1 x 5
#>   stemID quadrat sp      dbh     n
#>    <int> <chr>   <chr> <dbl> <int>
#> 1      3 0001    sp2    3.63     1
